The studies also suggest that CBT may be more effective for patients with high levels of psychosocial dysfunction, and that a brief CBT intervention can produce significant improvements in pain, disability, and psychological measures. Additionally, a tailored CBT intervention for patients with elevated levels of TMD pain-related interference with daily activities, independent of physical diagnosis, was found to be effective in improving pain-related variables over the course of treatment. The studies also highlight the importance of early identification and intervention for patients at high risk of progressing from acute to chronic TMD-related pain. Furthermore, a r and omized clinical trial found that a biopsychosocial intervention with patients at high risk of progressing from acute to chronic TMD-related pain was cost-effective, as patients in the intervention group spent significantly fewer jaw-related healthcare dollars compared to the control group. Overall, the studies support the use of CBT as a biopsychosocial approach for managing TMD pain and disability.

The studies reviewed in this summary all focus on the cost-effectiveness of fall prevention programs for older adults. Study 1 found that a multidisciplinary fall prevention program in nursing homes was not conclusively shown to be cost-effective. Study 2 evaluated a nurse-delivered home exercise program and found that it was effective in reducing falls and injuries in elderly people, with serious injuries and hospital admissions due to falls also reduced. Study 3 also evaluated a nurse-delivered home exercise program and found that it was equally effective in men and women, with the program costing $NZ418 per person to deliver for one year or $NZ1519 per fall prevented. Study 4 compared a community group exercise program and a home-based exercise program with usual care for older people and found that the FaME program increased self-reported physical activity levels among community-dwelling older adults 12 months after the intervention and significantly reduced falls. Study 5 evaluated a multifactorial fall prevention program in Denmark and found that it was not conclusively shown to be cost-effective. Study 6 assessed the cost-effectiveness of a home hazard reduction program to reduce falls among older persons and found that it was not cost-effective for younger participants but should be combined with other successful interventions for older people. The studies highlight the importance of fall prevention programs for older adults and the need for further research to determine the cost-effectiveness of individual components of multifactorial intervention packages, such as home modifications.

A review of eight studies related to exercise and cystic fibrosis (CF) has yielded several key findings. Firstly, a six-month conditioning program improved peak oxygen uptake, maximal workload, vigorous physical activity, forced vital capacity, and perceived health in patients with CF, with these benefits persisting for up to two years after the program ended (Study #1). Secondly, patients with CF hospitalized for an acute respiratory exacerbation spent less time doing physical activity compared to one month post-discharge, but activity levels were higher than anticipated, suggesting an increased metabolic rate (Study #2). Thirdly, osteopenia and osteoporosis are common in adults and adolescents with CF, with patients at highest risk being those with severe disease and those using corticosteroids (Study #3). Fourthly, anaerobic training improved anaerobic performance, aerobic performance, and health-related quality of life in children with CF, with these benefits sustained for up to 12 weeks after the program ended (Study #4). Fifthly, a partially supervised training program improved FEV1 in patients with CF, with these benefits persisting for up to 18 months off training, but regular long-term training is essential for treatment in CF (Study #5). Sixthly, the Habitual Activity Estimation Scale (HAES) questionnaire is a reliable and valid tool for measuring physical activity in patients with CF (Study #6). Lastly, a three-month supervised running program increased exercise tolerance, peak oxygen consumption, and respiratory muscle endurance in CF patients, with no adverse effects, suggesting that a longer program may have further benefits (Study #8). Overall, these studies highlight the importance of exercise in managing CF and the need for accurate methods to quantify physical activity in this population.

The reviewed studies suggest that a low-saturated-fat diet since infancy can lead to lower blood pressure in children and adolescents. A study found that children receiving a low-saturated-fat counseling through childhood had lower systolic and diastolic blood pressures than control children. Another study found that a web-based childhood obesity prevention program delivered online to promote healthy lifestyles and weights in Chinese American adolescents resulted in significant decreases in waist-to-hip ratio and diastolic blood pressure, and increases in vegetable and fruit intake, level of physical activity, and knowledge about physical activity and nutrition. The studies also indicate that higher levels of emotional dietary support from family members are associated with better adherence to a low sodium diet in African American girls as compared to boys. Caffeine consumption can lead to significant hemodynamic and humoral effects in habitual coffee drinkers that persist for many hours during the activities of everyday life, and caffeine may exaggerate sympathetic adrenal-medullary responses to the stressful events of normal daily life. A low-fat dairy consumption was associated with a lower risk of incident hypertension in a Mediterranean cohort, while whole-fat dairy consumption led to weight gain in a young nonhypertensive population. The DASH diet, which is rich in vegetables, fruits, and low-fat dairy products, was associated with lower systolic blood pressure at each sodium level, and the difference was greater with high sodium levels than with low ones. The reduction of sodium intake to levels below the current recommendation of 100 mmol per day and the DASH diet both lower blood pressure substantially, with greater effects in combination than singly. A school-based health promotion intervention program for African-American adolescents was efficacious in knowledge, exercise, and fruit and vegetable intake, but differences in systolic and diastolic blood pressure levels were not significant. Breastfeeding has been associated with lower blood pressure in later life, and breastmilk consumption was associated with lower later mean arterial pressure in children born prematurely.

A review of ten clinical studies related to the use of dual alpha and beta adrenergic receptor blockers (dual receptor blockers) in the treatment of hypertension has been synthesized. The studies investigated the effects of various types of dual receptor blockers, including carvedilol, propranolol, metoprolol, labetalol, and atenolol, on blood pressure, heart rate, and other related parameters.

The findings of the studies suggest that dual receptor blockers are effective in reducing blood pressure, both in the short and long term. Carvedilol, in particular, was found to have a significant antihypertensive effect, both acutely and after chronic treatment, and was also shown to have renal vasodilating properties. Labetalol, when administered once daily, was found to be less effective than other dual receptor blockers, such as carvedilol and atenolol, but was still effective in reducing blood pressure when given in higher doses.

The studies also investigated the effects of dual receptor blockers on heart rate and other related parameters. Propranolol and metoprolol were found to be more effective than labetalol in reducing heart rate, while labetalol was found to have a greater effect in reducing diastolic blood pressure, particularly in the upright position.

The studies also evaluated the safety and tolerability of the drugs. Side effects were generally mild, with dizziness and postural hypotension being the most commonly reported adverse events.

Overall, the studies suggest that dual receptor blockers are effective and well-tolerated treatments for hypertension, with carvedilol being a particularly promising option due to its antihypertensive and renal vasodilating properties. However, further research is needed to determine the optimal dosing and duration of treatment for these drugs.

The studies also highlight the importance of patient preference and the need for further research to determine the maximum potential effect size of interventions.

A study comparing traditional cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) with two augmented versions of CBT, schema therapy, and appetite-focused CBT, found no significant differences among the three therapy groups in reducing binge eating. However, all groups showed large effect sizes for improvement in binge eating, other eating disorder symptoms, and overall functioning. Another study evaluated an individualized lifestyle and life skills intervention for preventing antipsychotic-induced weight gain in young people with first-episode psychosis and found that the intervention group experienced significantly less weight gain than the control group. A study examining the long-term efficacy of a short-term CBT for binge eating disorder found that elevated weight, eating concern, and higher frequency of objective binges at the end of treatment predicted long-term success. The authors suggest that tailoring additional interventions to patients' individual needs could further improve treatment efficacy. A study investigating predictors and moderators of response to CBT and medication treatments for binge-eating disorder found that overvaluation of shape/weight was the most salient predictor/moderator of outcomes, with participants with overvaluation having significantly greater reductions in eating disorder psychopathology and depression levels if receiving CBT. The study also found that lower self-esteem, negative affect, and overvaluation signaled better improvements if receiving CBT, while younger participants had greater binge-eating reductions if receiving medication only. These findings have clinical utility for prescription of CBT and medication and implications for refining the binge-eating disorder diagnosis.

The studies discussed in this summary cover various aspects of gallstone disease, including the prevalence of gallstones, the accuracy of ultrasound in diagnosing gallstones, the effectiveness of laparoscopic and minilaparotomy cholecystectomy, the natural history of gallstone disease, and the feasibility and safety of observation versus surgery for symptomatic gallstone disease. The studies suggest that laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a safe and effective treatment for gallstone disease, with a success rate of at least 90% in both open and laparoscopic procedures. The studies discussed in this summary all focus on the effects of blood pressure lowering on stroke and cardiovascular disease. Here is a summary of the key findings:

A meta-analysis of 13 randomized controlled trials involving over 420,000 participants found that lowering diastolic blood pressure (DBP) was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of stroke and coronary heart disease (CHD). The association was continuous and appeared to be independent of the level of DBP. The study also found that the regression dilution bias, which underestimates the true association due to fluctuations in DBP, should be corrected for in future analyses.

2. A r and omized trial of over 880 elderly patients with hypertension found a significant reduction in fatal stroke and all strokes (fatal and non-fatal) in the treatment group, compared to the control group. The study used a combination of atenolol and bendrofluazide as the principal antihypertensive agents.

3. A study of over 1,000 patients with cerebrovascular disease found that lowering blood pressure was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of stroke, both fatal and non-fatal. The study also found that severe strokes were associated with a fall in blood pressure, which may have contributed to the J-shaped association between blood pressure and recurrent stroke sometimes reported in these patients.

4. A study of over 1,200 patients with hypertension and previous brain infarction found that acebutolol, a beta-blocker, reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure during the daytime but had little effect during the night and the morning. Slow-release nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, produced a consistent reduction in blood pressure over the entire 24-hour period and effectively blunted the rise in blood pressure in the morning. Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, produced a mild reduction in blood pressure with little change in the circadian pattern. The study suggests that the effects of antihypertensive agents on circadian blood pressure should be considered in hypertensive patients with previous brain infarction to reduce stroke recurrence.

The study suggests that EMD may represent an alternative to SCTG for treating Miller Class I and II gingival recessions by reducing surgical time and patient morbidity, but with lower complete root coverage than SCTG.

The studies reviewed all focus on preventing type 2 diabetes through lifestyle interventions, particularly weight loss. Study #1 found that initial weight loss, rather than weight loss goals, was positively associated with long-term weight loss in obese patients. Study #2 described a training curriculum for community workers to deliver a group-based adaptation of the Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) lifestyle intervention in YMCA settings. Study #3 found that a lifestyle intervention designed to achieve and maintain ideal body weight in men with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) significantly reduced the incidence of diabetes over a 4-year period. Study #4 argued that social policy is the key to achieving widespread reductions in both the incidence and prevalence of diabetes, as diabetes and obesity are closely intertwined and international r and omized controlled trials demonstrate that type 2 diabetes can be prevented or delayed through lifestyle modification. Study #5 found that a brief, small-group weight loss intervention was effective in promoting weight loss in individuals at risk of type 2 diabetes, but did not reach a broad population. Study #6 found that adding e-mail counseling to a basic Internet weight loss intervention program significantly improved weight loss in adults at risk of diabetes. Study #7 reported that a community-based lifestyle intervention program successfully encouraged weight loss to prevent diabetes in underserved minority communities, where prediabetes prevalence may be higher than previously reported. Study #8 found that interactive voice response (IVR) calls targeting physical activity and nutrition weight loss strategies were feasible and effective for patients with pre-diabetes. Study #9 described the direct medical, direct nonmedical, and indirect costs of the DPP interventions to prevent or delay type 2 diabetes, finding that the metformin and lifestyle interventions were associated with modest incremental costs compared with the placebo intervention. Study #10 reported the feasibility of implementing a diabetes prevention program (DPP) in a rural African-American church, with a high attendance rate and significant weight loss after the intervention and 12-month follow-up. Overall, these studies suggest that lifestyle interventions, particularly weight loss programs, are effective in preventing type 2 diabetes, but challenges remain in translating these lessons to routine health care settings and reaching broad populations, particularly in underserved communities.

A review of several studies investigating the effects of iron therapy on psychomotor development and cognitive function in iron-deficient children under three years old has yielded some key findings. Firstly, studies have consistently shown that iron-deficient children, both anemic and non-anemic, have lower scores on tests of mental and motor development compared to iron-sufficient children. Secondly, short-term oral iron therapy has not been found to significantly improve developmental scores in iron-deficient anemic infants, despite an excellent hematologic response. Thirdly, a study using auditory brainstem responses found that iron-deficient anemic infants at six months of age had longer central conduction times, suggesting altered myelination as a possible explanation for the adverse effects on CNS development. Fourthly, a r and omised double-blind trial in Indonesia found that iron supplementation improved developmental delays in iron-deficient anemic infants to the level of performance of iron-sufficient infants. Fifthly, a study found that behavioral rating data revealed significant differences between iron-deficient anemic and control groups, with the control group rated as more responsive, suggesting that iron deficiency may have lasting effects on behavior and development. Sixthly, a double-blind r and omised intervention study found that iron-deficient anemic children had increased rates of weight gain and more achieved the expected rate of development after receiving iron and vitamin C for two months. Lastly, a prospective cohort study found that anemic infants had significantly lower indices than control or non-anemic, iron-deficient infants, and that iron deficiency progressing to anemia was correlated with significantly lower motor and mental scores, suggesting adverse influences in the performance of developmental tests that persist despite iron therapy. Overall, these findings suggest that iron deficiency, alone or in association with anemia, may have lasting effects on behavior and development, and that routine child health surveillance in underprivileged areas should include a hemoglobin determination.

The study also found that consuming fructose instead of glucose in a high-fat, high-cholesterol diet increased the levels of risk factors associated with heart disease, particularly in hyperinsulinemic men. However, a study on patients with type 2 diabetes found that substituting moderate amounts of fructose for complex carbohydrates improved glycemic control and insulin sensitivity. Another study found that consuming very high amounts of fructose or glucose in hyperenergetic diets for four weeks did not significantly affect insulin sensitivity, liver fat, visceral fat, subcutaneous abdominal fat, or intramyocellular lipids in healthy participants. A study using typical American foods found no difference in fasting glucose, insulin, or lipid levels between consuming physiologic amounts of fructose or sucrose. Overall, the studies suggest that consuming high amounts of fructose, particularly in the context of a high-fat, high-cholesterol diet, may increase the levels of risk factors associated with heart disease, but moderate amounts of fructose may improve glycemic control and insulin sensitivity in people with type 2 diabetes.

Future longer-term studies are recommended to further investigate the benefits and potential risks of these dietary interventions.

The review background for this set of study abstracts is focused on the use of interproximal enamel reduction as a method for gaining space in orthodontic treatment. The studies included in this summary evaluate various techniques for interproximal enamel reduction, as well as their indications, contraindications, and complications.

Study #1 compared total arch distalization using orthodontic mini-implants (OMIs) with interproximal stripping (IPS) and second premolar extraction in Class I malocclusion patients. Both methods resulted in similar amounts of crowding and incisor retraction resolution.

Study #2 investigated the influence of attachments and interproximal reduction on canine rotation with Invisalign. The study found that vertical-ellipsoid attachments and interproximal reduction did not significantly improve the accuracy of canine rotation with the Invisalign system.

Study #3 assessed the surface roughness of enamel after various interproximal polishing methods. The studies discussed in this summary focus on the effectiveness of various methods for assessing and managing cardiovascular risk, including the use of risk profiles, health risk appraisal tools, and patient education. Some studies found that providing patients with personalized risk profiles did not significantly improve risk factors for coronary heart disease, while others found that health screening and feedback on risk profiles did not significantly increase physical activity or estimated cardiovascular risk over a one-month period. One study found that discussing perceived risk factors and sociodemographic variables on subjects' perception of heart attack risk did not accurately reflect objective measures of risk. Another study found that providing patients with personalized 10-year cardiovascular risk estimates did not significantly increase physical activity or estimated cardiovascular risk over a one-month period. However, some studies found that discussing coronary heart disease risk profiles in addition to guidelines did not significantly improve risk factors for coronary heart disease in patients on combination antiretroviral therapy, and that providing patients with health screening and feedback on risk profiles did not significantly increase psychological distress over a five-year follow-up period. Overall, the studies suggest that while some methods for assessing and managing cardiovascular risk may be effective, more research is needed to determine the long-term psychological and behavioral impacts of these methods, and to explore medication disutility in larger population samples.

The studies reviewed in this article suggest that calcium supplementation can prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, particularly in the lumbar spine, proximal femur, and total body. The effects of calcium supplementation on bone loss are weaker than those of estrogen, bisphosphonates, or calcitonin therapy, indicating that calcium supplements alone cannot substitute for these in treating established osteoporosis. However, because of their safety, high tolerance, and low expense, calcium supplements may be a useful preventive measure for elderly postmenopausal women whose bone mineral density values are normal for their age. Calcium supplementation also reduces bone loss in men and middle-aged women, particularly in postmenopausal women. The studies also suggest that calcium supplementation can counteract a large portion of the additional bone loss attributable to menopause in this population. The effects of calcium supplementation on bone loss are consistent across different techniques for measuring bone density, such as radiogrammetry, photon absorptiometry, and dual-energy quantitative computed tomography. The studies also suggest that calcium supplementation can reduce the incidence of nonvertebral fractures in older persons living in the community. Overall, the studies support the use of calcium supplements as a preventive measure for bone loss in certain populations.

The studies cover a range of interventions, including the use of extensively hydrolyzed casein-based formula (EHCF), amino acid-based formula (AAF), probiotics, and synbiotics. The studies also assess the impact of these interventions on growth, tolerance, and immune system modulation. The results of these studies suggest that EHCF may lead to reduced weight gain in infants during the first year of life, but has no long-term consequences on body mass index (BMI) for up to 10 years of age. AAF and synbiotics-supplemented AAF support normal growth and have no long-term consequences on BMI. Probiotic bacteria, particularly viable but not heat-inactivated Lactobacillus GG (LGG), may be a potential approach for the management of atopic eczema and CMA in breast-fed infants. However, the use of LGG as an adjunct to maternal cow's milk restriction in breast-fed infants with rectal bleeding is not supported by the results of a pilot study. The acquisition of tolerance to cow's milk through probiotic supplementation, specifically a combination of Lactobacillus casei CRL431 and Bifidobacterium lactis Bb-12, does not appear to accelerate tolerance in infants with CMA. The studies also suggest that probiotic intake is confirmed by the isolation of viable probiotics from feces more often in treated infants than in the placebo group. The studies highlight the importance of viability in the management of CMA through probiotic supplementation.

Some studies suggest that orthotic intervention may prevent or slow the progression of hallux valgus deformity in rheumatoid arthritic feet, while others suggest that orthotic intervention may not improve gait in patients with metatarsalgia due to rheumatoid arthritis. The studies also suggest that foot orthoses may be effective enough in terms of foot pain and function for specific patients with rheumatoid foot problems, regardless of the location of foot pathology. Overall, the studies suggest that orthotic intervention may provide some benefits for patients with rheumatoid arthritis, but further research is needed to determine the optimal type, location, and duration of orthotic intervention for different patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

The studies discussed in this summary all focus on the benefits of preoperative pulmonary rehabilitation for patients with lung cancer or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) undergoing lung surgery. Here is a summary of the key findings:

1. A systematic review and meta-analysis of 11 studies found that preoperative pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) significantly reduced postoperative complications and mortality in patients with lung cancer or COPD undergoing lung surgery.

2. A randomized controlled trial found that a 4-week preoperative PR program improved physical performance and respiratory function in patients with both lung cancer and COPD, and this advantage was maintained after surgery.

3. A randomized controlled trial found that a 7-day intensive preoperative PR program combined with inspiratory muscle training and aerobic endurance training in elderly patients with lung cancer significantly reduced postoperative pulmonary complications and hospital stay.

4. A study of 40 patients with biopsy-proven non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) stages I to IIIa referred for surgical resection found that a preoperative home-based exercise program was not feasible due to interfering diagnostic procedures and fast-track surgery. However, the study did find that an early postoperative exercise program involving resistance and high-intensity interval cardiorespiratory exercise was safe and feasible.

5. A study of 1021 men diagnosed with cancer (other than nonmelanoma skin cancer) found that engaging in physical activity after cancer diagnosis was associated with better survival among men.

6. A study of 124 patients with biopsy-proven NSCLC stages I to IIIa referred for surgical resection found that the early postoperative exercise program for patients with NSCLC was safe and feasible, but the preoperative home-based exercise program was not feasible due to interfering diagnostic procedures and fast-track surgery.

Overall, these studies suggest that preoperative PR can improve physical performance, respiratory function, and reduce postoperative complications and mortality in patients with lung cancer or COPD undergoing lung surgery. However, the feasibility and timing of preoperative PR may vary depending on the specific population and healthcare setting.

The studies presented in this summary focus on the use of androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) for the treatment of prostate cancer. Study 1 compares the efficacy of ADT with or without concurrent radiation therapy in patients with localized prostate cancer. The study found that ADT did not significantly improve biochemical recurrence-free survival in patients with low-risk disease, but did improve outcomes in those with high-risk disease. Study 2 examines the use of ADT in patients with biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy. The study found that early discontinuation of ADT was associated with a higher risk of castration resistance and death. Study 3 compares the efficacy of total intermittent androgen blockade versus total continuous androgen blockade in the treatment of patients with advanced prostate cancer. The study found that intermittent ADT was as effective as continuous ADT in maintaining androgen-dependent state of advanced prostate cancer. Study 4 investigates the use of ADT in patients with hormone-naive advanced or relapsing prostate cancer. The study found that degarelix, a new type of ADT, was as effective as leuprolide in suppressing testosterone and prostate-specific antigen levels. Study 5 compares the efficacy of degarelix and leuprolide regarding prostate-specific antigen recurrence-free survival in patients with prostate cancer. The study found that degarelix offered improved PSA control compared to leuprolide, particularly in patients with advanced disease or high baseline PSA levels. Overall, these studies suggest that ADT can be an effective treatment for prostate cancer, particularly in patients with high-risk disease or advanced disease. The use of intermittent ADT and degarelix as an alternative to continuous ADT is also being explored as a potential treatment option. However, further studies are needed to confirm these findings and to determine the long-term effects of ADT on survival.

The review background of this collection of study abstracts is focused on assessing the impact of computers and computer-based clinical decision support systems on the management of hypertension. The studies cover various interventions, such as computer-administered cognitive-behavioral therapy, computerized decision support for lipid management, computerized decision support for oral anticoagulation management, computer-held medical records, computer feedback for hypertension control, computerized reminders for blood pressure screening, and a computer program for treating hypertension.

The studies show that computer-administered cognitive-behavioral therapy is effective in treating depression, with both computer- and therapist-administered therapy resulting in significant improvements in symptoms. A computerized decision support system for lipid management in primary care did not have the expected uptake, but it did result in a significant decrease in referrals to secondary care for the investigation of hyperlipidaemia. The computerized decision support system for oral anticoagulation management in primary care resulted in improved INR control and a significant extension in mean recall times. The computer feedback for hypertension control in primary care resulted in more patients being seen and a longer mean recall time, but there was no significant difference in blood pressure control between the intervention and control groups. The computerized reminders for blood pressure screening in primary care resulted in modest improvements in compliance, with the physician reminder being the most cost-effective. The computer program for treating hypertension resulted in similar blood pressure responses and drug side effects as physician-treated patients, suggesting that a computer program could guide allied health workers in settings where expert physicians are scarce.

Overall, the studies suggest that computer-based interventions can have a positive impact on the management of hypertension, but further improvements may need to come from outside the traditional medical model. Strategies for improving outpatient hypertension management may involve a combination of routine reminders to physicians, followed by letters to noncompliant patients.

The studies discussed in this summary cover a range of topics related to low back pain, including the effectiveness of various treatments, the role of radiography in primary care, socioeconomic factors and disability retirement, the implementation of clinical practice guidelines, and the influence of education and socioeconomic position on disability retirement. Some key findings and implications include:

- Spinal manipulation and mobilization are effective treatments for acute low back pain, with spinal manipulation being more effective than mobilization.
- Spinal manipulation is not associated with serious adverse events, and patients receiving manipulation are more satisfied with their care.
- Lumbar spine radiography in primary care patients with low back pain is not associated with improved functioning or overall health status, and patients receiving radiography are more satisfied with their care but are not less worried or more reassured about serious disease causing their low back pain.
- Each year of formal education is independently associated with decreased risk for disability retirement from noninflammatory back pain and inflammatory back pain, and disability from inflammatory back pain is moderately associated with socioeconomic status.
- The implementation of clinical practice guidelines for low-back pain with primary care physicians in a large community can improve therapeutic results for patients without delaying the return to work.
- Sociocultural factors influence the expression of low back pain, but not the risk of chronicity once low back pain is reported, and work satisfaction may not be causally related to low back pain but may intervene along with type of occupation in the possibility of continuing employment once low back pain is present.
- Further research is needed to confirm these findings and elucidate causal relationships.

Some studies also investigate the potential role of bipolar disorder in SAD and the effectiveness of tryptophan depletion and reboxetine in treating SAD. The findings suggest that SAD is a significant public health concern, and that the serotonin system may be involved in the mechanism of action of light therapy. The studies also provide estimates of the circadian component of SAD, which may apply to the antidepressant mechanism of action of appropriately timed bright light exposure. Overall, the studies provide insights into the pathophysiology and treatment of SAD, as well as suggest ways to assess the circadian component of other psychiatric, sleep, and chronobiologic disorders.

Several studies have investigated the effects of vegetarian diets on lipid levels. One study found that a low-fat vegetarian diet led to greater improvements in total and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels than a low-fat diet that included more animal products. Another study found that a plant-based diet consistent with the revised American Heart Association guidelines led to greater LDL cholesterol-lowering benefits than a more typical low-fat diet that was identical in intake of total fat, saturated fat, and cholesterol. Both studies suggest that a plant-based diet can be an effective approach to lipid management. However, the specific components of the plant-based diets that contribute to these benefits are not fully understood. Some studies have focused on individual dietary factors or foods, such as soy protein, plant sterols, and soluble fiber, while others have focused on modifying multiple dietary components simultaneously, such as increasing intake of vegetables and whole grains. Further research is needed to determine the most effective ways to incorporate these dietary factors into a plant-based diet for lipid management.

The study suggests that MCTs may decrease the risk of cardiovascular events in hyperlipidemic, overweight men by lowering plasma LDL-C without significantly changing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol concentrations.

The results showed that plasma LDL-C levels decreased in the MCT and olive oil groups, without significantly changing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol concentrations. In contrast, the use of Adper Prompt L-Pop and Copalite as liners under amalgam restorations significantly reduced cold sensitivity at all assessment time points, 24 hours, one week, and one month post-treatment, according to two separate studies.

A systematic review was conducted to evaluate the incidence rate of root fractures in post-retained restorations. Study #1 reported a higher failure rate for carbon fiber reinforced carbon posts compared to conventional wrought precious alloy posts. Study #2 introduced a tool for assessing risk of bias in randomized trials. Study #3 found satisfactory clinical performance for both glass fiber post design and core build-up material, with a high overall survival rate of 98.5%. Study #4 reported no post or core failures in groups using conventional tapered cast posts or ParaPost system prefabricated gold posts with cast cores, with a low overall failure rate of 6%. Study #5 found both cast gold and composite post and core systems performed well clinically, with a high success and survival probability at 3 years. Study #6 found restorations with fiber posts and composite were more effective than amalgam in preventing root fractures but less effective in preventing secondary caries. Study #7 reported comparable long-term survival rates for glass fiber-reinforced epoxy resin posts and titanium posts, with high survival rates for both materials. Overall, the review suggests that post-retained restorations have satisfactory clinical performance, with some differences in failure rates between post materials. However, longer follow-up times are needed to detect significant differences.

The studies discussed in this summary aim to improve the diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis, a condition characterized by low bone mass and an increased risk of fractures, particularly in postmenopausal women. The studies use various approaches, such as patient education, physician alerting systems, case manager interventions, and facilitated bone mineral density testing, to increase the rate of osteoporosis investigation and treatment after fragility fractures, which are low-trauma fractures commonly associated with osteoporosis. The studies report significant improvements in bisphosphonate use, bone mineral density testing, and receipt of appropriate care for osteoporosis after hip fracture and wrist fracture, with the more intensive and expensive interventions resulting in higher rates of appropriate management. The studies also highlight the need for efficient and measurable systems of disease management that reconcile conflicts between socioeconomic responsibility and patient welfare, and the importance of clinical guidelines in simplifying medical decision making and helping physicians and patients make good decisions about skeletal health and osteoporosis. The studies suggest that healthcare professionals, including family physicians, pharmacists, and nurses, can play a key role in early identification of osteoporosis and that multifaceted interventions, such as the Recognizing Osteoporosis and its Consequences in Quebec (ROCQ) programme, can help to decrease the gaps in diagnostic and treatment care for osteoporosis following fragility fractures. The studies also emphasize the need for further research to measure the association between fragility fractures and future fracture risk and to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions on the diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis.

The studies also highlight the need for more data on utilities in patients receiving statins and the long-term effects of statin therapy in older patients.

Study #27: Effects of simvastatin and ciprofibrate alone and in combination on lipid profile, plasma fibrinogen and low density lipoprotein particle structure and distribution in patients with familial combined hyperlipidaemia and coronary artery disease.

- At baseline, apoB, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides were increased, whereas LDL particles were small and dense.
- Drug combination and ciprofibrate significantly reduced plasma fibrinogen (-24%), triglycerides (-51%), and total and LDL cholesterol (-25% and -22%, respectively) compared to simvastatin (-10% and -22%, respectively) for LDL cholesterol.
- Ciprofibrate and drug combination increased LDL particle size (-0.24 versus -0.61) and reduced the triglyceride content of all LDL subfractions except LDL2 (-0.24 versus -0.18) for LDL particles.
- Simvastatin reduced the cholesterol content of all LDL subfractions except LDL2 (-0.18 versus -0.24) for LDL particles.
- Ciprofibrate and drug combination reduced the triglyceride content of all LDL subfractions.
- Ciprofibrate and drug combination reduced fibrinogen (-25%) and uric acid (-25%) in type IIa and type IIb patients.
- Safety parameters reflected drug-specific known side effects, underscoring the safety of both drugs in addition to their efficacy in lipid lowering.

The studies reviewed in this report evaluated the efficacy of various antimicrobial agents and oral hygiene products in preventing and reducing dental plaque and gingivitis. The studies used different designs, such as parallel-group, crossover, and blinded studies, and assessed various parameters, such as plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, and crevicular leukocytes. The studies found that triclosan, stannous fluoride, and cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC) were effective in reducing plaque and gingivitis, either alone or in combination with other ingredients. The studies also compared the efficacy of different products, such as Listerine, a triclosan/copolymer/fluoride dentifrice, and a CPC-detergent formulation, and found that some products were more effective than others. The studies suggest that oral hygiene regimens that utilize antimicrobial agents, such as triclosan and CPC, can significantly reduce pre-existing plaque and gingivitis above what is accomplished by traditional fluoride-containing dentifrices. However, some studies found that a conventional fluoride toothpaste was as effective as an antiseptic mouthrinse in preventing plaque and gingivitis. Overall, the studies provide evidence for the clinical efficacy of antimicrobial agents and oral hygiene products in preventing and reducing dental plaque and gingivitis.

A review of seven studies investigating the effectiveness of antidepressants in treating depression in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) has been synthesized. The studies compared the use of low doses of amitriptyline, fluoxetine, pramipexole, sertraline, desipramine, citalopram, and nefazodone. The findings suggest that antidepressants, including SSRIs and a dopamine agonist, can be effective in treating depression in PD patients. However, some studies reported adverse effects, such as motor complications and side effects, particularly with tricyclic antidepressants. Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) was found to be as effective as fluoxetine in treating depression in PD patients, with the added advantage of some motor improvement and earlier cognitive improvement, and fewer adverse effects. Nefazodone, a serotonin 2 antagonist/reuptake inhibitor (SARI), was found to have a dual activity as an antidepressant and as an agent capable of reducing extrapyramidal symptoms in depressed PD patients. Overall, the studies suggest that antidepressants can be beneficial in treating depression in PD patients, but the choice of medication should be carefully considered based on individual patient characteristics and potential side effects.

The studies reviewed in this summary focus on various interventions aimed at improving weight management, physical fitness, and cardiovascular health in military personnel. Some studies explore the effectiveness of dietary interventions, such as the Food Guide Pyramid and the Fat Loss and Exercise Program, while others examine the impact of exercise programs, such as the Fitness for Life program and the FFT program. Some studies also explore the use of technology, such as the Internet-based weight-management interventions and the Polar F61 pedometer, to promote weight loss and physical activity. The studies highlight the importance of addressing weight gain prevention and the need for population-based efforts to prevent annual weight gain in working adults. The studies also emphasize the importance of assessing knowledge, anxiety, stress, nutrition intake, and body composition in military personnel and delivering evidence-based interventions to improve their health outcomes, particularly for female athletes who struggle harder than male athletes to lose body fat and maintain a leaner physique. Overall, the studies suggest that a multidisciplinary team approach to the treatment of obesity, including psychology, internal medicine, nursing, nutrition care, and physical therapy, can be effective in preventing weight gain and improving cardiovascular health in military personnel.

The summary of the studies suggests that various techniques can help individuals with weight issues manage their food cravings and impulsivity. These techniques include response inhibition training, acceptance-based strategies, mindful eating, non-food odorants, learning choices, exercise, and brisk walking. These techniques have been shown to reduce chocolate cravings, delay discounting for food, impulsivity, and ad libitum snacking, and increase self-control and regulatory fit. The studies also suggest that exercise can reduce attentional bias and chocolate cravings, and that learning in a controlled choice environment can lead to less snack consumption and better self-regulation task performance. The value from fit proposal suggests that people experience a regulatory fit when they use goal pursuit means that fit their regulatory orientation, and this regulatory fit increases the value of what they are doing. Overall, these studies provide insights into potential techniques that can help individuals manage their food cravings and impulsivity, which may have implications for weight loss maintenance strategies.
